Posts.Content: julie26 wrote: I'm sorry if I tend to repeat myself over and over but I continue to struggle with the same issues.  The lack of sleep is terrible and is really starting to get to me.  I thank you for all the recommendations but can't seem to find the right combination that works for me. I tend to fall asleep on the couch around 8:00 or 9:00 pm and sleep for an hour 1/2 to 2 hours.   I called the Advice Nurse in tears a few days ago and she recommended that I go get a nice massage which I did. It was very nice and relaxing but of course I cannot afford to do that all the time. She told me to resist falling asleep on the couch and do not watch TV, read, etc in bed. Well I did that and believe it or not, I slept 5 1/2 hours!!!  It was great but of course it's not happened since.  I slept on the couch for a couple of hours early last night from about maybe 9:00 pm  to 11:00 and have been up ever since and it's after 7:00 am. I feel like I'm going out of my mind.  I just don't know what to do anymore.  I am really trying not to dwell on the fact that I am dying but it's so hard especially when I'm home alone all day.  I look terrible between my very puffy steroid face (and body) along with the bags under my eyes from lack of sleep. My hair was short (I was told it would never come back in after WBR and SRS but it did).  I starts growing back and sticking out all over the place and I spend so much time trying to gel it down. I went and got it cut really (really) short yesterday. Now my face looks even fatter.  It does grow very fast so in a week or two it will look better. In the meantime, I can throw a wig or a hat on if I want. I'm usually just home alone so it will be more comfortable for me around the house.  I could certainly handle things alot better if I were getting sleep. It has been a long 11 years dealing with cancer but things really changed after after the lung mets (3 years ago) and really changed after the brain mets (a little over a year ago).  I miss working, getting out of the house, being around people and feeling a sense of accomplishment. It's very hard to sit around the house. It's also hard to know that I am dying. I think about how much I will miss my son, husband, family and friends.  I love where we live. I look around and think about how I will not be here anymore.  I'm cooking a small Thanksgiving dinner this year, it will be nice.  I am just hoping so bad for some sleep and peace with dealing with everything that is going on.  I don't want to dwell on the fact that I'm dying although I must admit that it is hard sometimes.  I still just can't believe it's finally come down to this although I knew it would someday.  Up to this point, I've always beaten the odds.  They told me I had 6 months or less left a little over a year ago. I would love to have another 6 months or year of quality time left. By the way, I am NOT depressed. I was depressed when my husband of 20+ years left me when I was first diagnosed with cancer (our son was only 7 yr. old at the time).  I took different antidepressants for maybe a year and hated them. Thank you for listening to me and sorry if I repeat myself a lot. It's just that seem to be struggling with the same issues. It's so hard for other people to understand that cannot relate. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Chemo was cancelled - Darn! julie26

Posts.Content: julie26 wrote: I have posted a few times over the years but have always read the posts. I figured it was time to do it again as I seem to be really struggling. To make a long story short, I was was first dx in right breast in 2001. I lumpectomy, AC and rad.  At the time I was going through a divorce after a 20+ yr. marriage and it was a very difficult time in my life.  I had a recurrence in left breast in 2005 and once again had lumpectomy, AC and rad then 1 year of Herceptin. (Stage I, no node involvement either time).  I remarried in 2005 and 2 years ago moved to an area that we've been wanting to move to for a long time and I love it here. Then the economy hit and effected us like so many others.  I was working part time then went back full time to help make ends meet.  In May of this year, I felt a lump above my breast by my previous port scar. I had been complaining for at least a year of pain in that area but nothing ever showed up.  This time I asked for a digital mammogram (I had just had a regular mammogram 9 months earlier that was clear as it was the other 2 both times I had cancer).  I also had an ultrasound of the lump which did not show up in the mammogram as it was above the breast. BINGO, CANCER!  I just knew that something was there. I also had a small tumor in the breast along with microcalcifications.  The lump I felt was actually a lymph node that had been engulfed by a 2 cm tumor. I had 3 other lymph nodes removed that were negative.  I had a CT scan and they found 6-10 nodules in the lungs that are of course suspicious for metastasis.  At the first meeting with the Onc. I was so upset over the lung issue.  She seemed like she was not very concerned about it at all.  She said they are small (the biggest is 6 mm) and that she cannot even biopsy them as they are so small.  I of course am freaking out and thinking cancer is going to win this time.  I asked her to be up front and to not sugar coat anything and she said she is.  She said she is not sure how to stage me and is treating this as a recurrence of the original cancer in 2001. (I wasTriple- the first time, ER/PR- and Her2+ the 2nd time and this time it is once again Triple-).  She said she is treating it aggressively as Stage 4 but honestly feels that I have a fighting chance.  She also said that half of it will be up to her and the medicine and the other half up to me. I have a friend that went to her and she was Stage IV and she was very up front and honest about that with her and did not sugar coat it. I am currently on Taxol and Avastin.  If all goes as planned, I will also have radiation (I've been radiated on each side before but this area is above the breast so they should be able to radiate again) then I'm supposed to have the other breast removed and reconstruction.  I am really trying to be positive and put up a good fight to beat this but I'm tired both physically and emotionally. Plus with my husband's work so slow and me on disability we are really struggling financially. I'm on State Disability.  Because of the way they go back so many quarters to figure your benefit amount, it went back to my part time pay, not my full time pay so I'm bringing home about 2/3 less than I was when I was working. I also pay $400 a month for my medical alone (on top of the co pays). I will be turning 50 in December and the new rates come out in January so I will be getting the regular rate increase in addition to going into a higher rate age bracket.  I miss working. I sit home every day by myself as my husband is at work and my 15 yr. old son is at school. Then he goes with his dad every weekend and my husband works every weekend. I have way too much time to think about things. I try to stay busy but it's hard. I do not have family close by and not many friends to get together with as we are fairly new to the area and all of my friends work.  Part of me wants to trust what the doctor is telling me and fight with all I have and part of me just wants to give up and throw in the towel.  It's hard, I just don't know what to do.  Sorry to ramble on so much. I just really needed to vent and I know that so many of you can understand. I think I will post this in both the Recurrence and Stage IV section. I'm just really lost right now. I'd appreciate any stories of hope  or encouragement that may be out there.  Thank you. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 30, 2012 07:17AM - edited May 30, 2012 07:21AM by julie26 I had WBR in September and SRS in March. I was told that my hair would never come back after the WBR (I'd already lost it 3 times before from various chemos).  Well it did come back. It took 4 or 5 months and I also had a bald strip down the middle at first but it has finally filled in. (I called it my "Reverse Mohawk"!!).  I got little round bald patches after the SRS but that has also filled in.  I'm glad I can at least put a baseball cap on and I have some hair underneath. I even did it when I had my bald strip as the hat covered it.  My problem now is it is just thick and fuzzy and I can't do much with it. But hey it's hair. I did go get the back and sideburns trimmed so at least it looks decent under the hat. Speaking of hair, I was first diagnosed 11 years ago at age 41. I had never cut my hair.  It was down to my calves and was very thick.  It was hard to lose all of it in the way that I did.  I'm 52 now so I'm thinking I'd probably be a little too old for all that hair now though!!  I have the long braid that I had cut off. My son thought it was cool at the time (he was 7). He turned 18 yesterday and now thinks it's creepy. I think I can still donate it.  The braid is probably 4 1/2 feet long and very thick. I'll have to check into that.  Hang in there. Your hair will fill in. It just takes time. I see that you live in Puyallup.  I used to live in Enumclaw and worked in Renton. I have a lot of family in the Puyallup, Auburn/Kent and Bremerton areas. WA is a beautiful state, I wish I would have stayed there. Take care.

I know some of that is because I have not let go of the past but to be honest, he really should not be married. He is 57 and never had children.  He was married before but it was a short term. He is very kind and has good intentions.  He thinks just working and providing is enough. He never had a long term, commited relationship or kids so he really doesn't know what it's like or what it entails.  He's never been involved with my son. He loves him and is good to him but he's not the type to go fishing, throw a ball, etc.  He is tired when he gets home from work and just watches TV every night.  We talk a little but it's usually about his work.  He really does not like to do much.  I love to be outside in the spring and summer.  We have a beautiful backyard and never go out there together. He does not really like to do yard work and only does it because he has to.  He does not like to do things on the house at all.  My ex and I lived on acreage and were always outside or always doing something on the house together. I miss that. I also miss things like going fishing, for a car ride, a picnic, etc.   I will admit I remarried on the rebound (I was married 21 years the first time).  I did it for all the wrong reasons. I was a single mom with a 7 yr. old son and had cancer.  I was scared. We were dating during my first diagnosis then got married right after I was diagnosed the second time.  Sorry, I know this is a breast cancer forum not a divorce forum.  I really don't want to take anti depressants as I took them at the beginning and did not like the way I felt on them.  (I tried different ones).  I do not feel down every day.  I am so grateful that I've lived long enough to see my son grow up. I always prayed that I just wanted to see him graduate from High School.  He will graduate next year.  I don't mean to sound ungrateful in any way as I know many women do not get the chance to see their children grow up.  I am very lucky. Sometimes it's just hard to deal with it all.  I'm really getting tired of treatments and would love to go back to work.  I'll try the volunteering thing and maybe take a class or two. I need to get out of this house. I do walk most days. We live in the foothills so it's very beautiful and I love to get out and walk. Some days I have to force myself as I'm exhausted but do feel better once I get out and do it. Again, thank you all for your support and encouragement. It means so much.  Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: julie26 wrote: I am having problems sleeping no matter what sleep medication that I take and feel that I am at my wit's end.  I try not to nap during the day but sometimes I will fall asleep in the chair for an hour or two. That kind of scares me as my Neuro Oncologist said that as the brain tumors progress, I will became more tired and want to sleep more. The reason it scares me is I'm not sure if that's why I am so tired or if it's because I'm just plain exhausted from not sleeping at night.  Ever since I had the Pericardial Effusion done several months ago, I get up several times during the night to use the bathroom so that is interrupting my sleep. I have fluid that drains and builds up in my abdominal cavity.  I drink water but that is not from that and my lips are very chapped and dry no matter how much water I drink.  I despise taking the Decadron as it makes me so jittery. I wish there was an alternative. Maybe I should talk to my Neuro Oncologist.  I have one more appt. with my Medical Oncologist next month.  My Neuro Oncologist wants me to start Hospice.  I told him that I am functioning fine.  I believe my Medical Oncologist also wants me to stop seeing her since there's not much she can do for me now that my treatment has been completely stopped.  I do not feel that I am ready for Hospice. I clean house, cook, do laundry, etc. with no problems. I'm not sure what Hospice would even do for me right now.  I have my husband and 18 yr. old son around to help me if I need anything.  I'm just not sure what to do anymore.  I'd appreciate any comments and/or feedback. (About a year before I met him).  He had radiation to his head and says that ever since then, he just seems to get so tired.  So maybe it's a little bit of that plus being boring!!  I am very outgoing and social so it makes it kind of hard.  He really does have a good heart and is a very kind, gentle (but boring!!) man.  I do get sad sometimes but as I said before, I do have joy in my life.  Things are just so different since my divorce. Posts.Content: julie26 wrote: I have both lung and brain mets.  I had chemo (Gemzar) on Thursday the Aug. 2nd.  2 days later I was in Emergency then hospitalized for 5 additional days.  They discovered that I had a pericardial effusion.  (fluid build up around the heart).  I had surgery and they put in a pericardial window to drain the fluid from around the heart into the chest cavity where it it less dangerous.  They biopsied the fluid and it is malignant (they said it usually is).  My Onc. had given me about 6 months to live after the brain mets were discovered which was 11 months ago and I'm still here. She told me things could change very fast and I think that is were we are now.  I will be seeing her on Thursday. I'm not sure what they will do at this point, if anything.  I am usually pretty tough but this has been pretty hard on me.  I'm thinking I don't have much longer to live now.  I am grateful that I got to see my son graduate and turn 18 in May. He was 7 years old the first time I was diagnosed.  I sure wish I had more time (but only if it were quality) My husband wants to take a trip. We were going to go to Hawaii but with all that's gone on, I cannot fly. He booked a trip at a beautiful hotel overlooking the ocean (In CA). I hope we can make it if even for just a couple of days.  I've been dealing with cancer for so long and always knew that someday it would probably win.  I think that time has come.  I guess I feel a little sad to leave my family.  Well thanks for listening. It's nice to have a place to vent where people truly understand where you are coming from. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: julie26 wrote: I met with the Thoracic Surgeon yesterday to discuss the PET Scan results and upcoming surgical biopsy.  The mediastinal lymph node lit up and had "intense uptake".  This was no surprise as it showed up on the recent CT Scan.  There was another spot in the left subpectoral area that had moderate uptake. That is the same area where I discovered the tumor 2 years ago that led to this 3rd diagnosis (I also had tumors in the left breast).  The Breast Surgeon told me when he did the surgery 2 years ago, that he could not be sure he got it all in that area and recommended I have rads. if I could (I've had already had rads. on both sides with the two previous cancers and they were not sure if that area was in the prior field of radiation or not. If it is, I would not be able to get rad. again anway).  Once they found out I had lung mets, the radiation took a back seat to treating the lungs.  This Surgeon said he is not too concerned with that spot as it could even be inflammation from the prior surgery (not sure how it can still be inflamed if surgery was 2 years ago). I will discuss that further with my Onc.  The good news is, the lungs are stable (yeah!) and there is no evidence of cancer anywhere else (yeah again!).  I am scheduled for a surgical biopsy on Aug. 8th. He will remove as much of the mediastinal lymph node was possible. The want to see if it is indeed breast cancer and not another kind of cancer (he believes it is) and if so, does have the same pathology as the BC they are now treating me for. I was scheduled for chemo on Aug. 4th but the Surgeon said he will contact my Onc. and recommend we skip that one so my immune system is as strong as it can be for the surgery.  I am of course not thrilled that the cancer has spread but am grateful the news was not worse as I know it could have been.  Once they get the path. report back, they will decide what chemo to change me to. (Currently on Taxol alone).  Prior CT scans have shown lung tumors are shrinking/disappearing but CA 15-3 continued to rise 4 months in a row (before it would fluctuate up and down).  That is why the Dr. ordered the CT and PET scans.  The CA 15-3 started "trending" up.  I'm not sure what lies ahead but I will just take it as it comes. Just like I have through out this 10 year journey. Thanks again for listening and all the support. I am so grateful for this site. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: PET scan results/surgery julie26 DiDel

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2010 12:03AM julie26 wrote: I am so sorry to hear that you have lung mets.  I was first dx in right breast in 2001, ER/PR- Her2-.  Had lumpectomy, chemo (A/C) and radiation.  Had a recurrence in the left breast in 2005. This time it was ER/PR- & Her2+.  Had same surgery and chemo again  along with a year of Herceptin.  Had another recurrence last year in the left breast.  This time it is Triple Negative Stage IV with lymphatic & vascular invasion.  On first CT Scan I had 10 nodules scattered through out both lungs.  I have been doing Avastin and Taxol for the past 15 months (I was going every week but had to change to every other week due to low white count).  The last 2 CT scans show that all but 2 of the nodules have disappeared and the 2 remaining ones have shrunk significantly!!!  My Tumor Marker CA 15-3 started at 31 and went up. It's now at 51 and seems to fluctuate between 47 -51.  At first I was worried about that but it does not seem to correlate with the CT scans. I know that you are scared. I am too at times. I am tolerating the chemo fairly well and am able to do most things.  I do get a little tired sometimes and have problems with my sinuses but I am not usually nauseous.  I just try to keep busy and also try to have a good attitude.  I figured that I can either waste what time I have left worrying and being scared all the time or I can try to enjoy it the best I can. I'm not saying that I don't ever get scared or worry because I do. I just try not to stay in that place too long.  Sometimes I wonder if I'll be here to see my son graduate from High School next year.  But then I wondered that when I was first diagnosed and he was only 7 years old then.  I also wondered it again the 2nd time I was diagnosed when he was 10 years old. He is now almost 17 and I'm still here!  It's not an easy thing to go through but my advise would be to just take one day at a time and do not think too far ahead as it can be overwhelming.  I wish you the best.
